reviewText: Blood Dragon is a much better game than the Far Cry 3 prefix would have you believe. It plays better, runs better, looks better, and actually has writing. Clever writing. It has undeniable style and some of the more fun weapons and combat I've seen in an FPS recently. It's not perfect, but it's a solid length and pretty fun. I imagine it's even a bit more fun if you were an 80s kid, but I can't speak to that.\n\nTry Blood Dragon, even if you're like me and disliked Far Cry 3. They actually put effort into this one.

reviewText:
Awesomesauce !
Set in 2007 but with an 80s look and feel, you are Rex Power Colt, a Mark IV Cyber Commando (best guy in the universe), whose mission is to stop his mentor Sloan whose gone rogue.The game's story is silly and fun, full of inside jokes at 80s movies and modern video games such as Alien and Assassin's Creed, The humor in the game is fantastic to say the least.
The game's mechanics are built upon the already amazing FarCry 3 mechanics, with a few twists of Cyber Poweres and Sci-Fi stuff... which is pretty cool. To run faster than a car and jump from the top of a mountain only to hear your Cyber legs laughing at Newton's laws of physics :)
The game has a huge map (about 40% of FarCry 3's map) filled with exciting outposts to overtake, many collectibles, Dino Dragons to fight (Dragon+Lizard beast) that shoot lazers !
The soundtrack is easily a 10/10
and all of this for a very very low price ? ($15 !)
9.5/10

Recently rebuilt / recovered from serious injuries and upgraded to Mk IV, you are sent with a buddy commando to infiltrate enemy compound to retrieve computer data... reviewText:
I absolutely loved FC3, and I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing love the 80s.  Infact, I'm going to go ahead and get my small complaints out of the way early so I can spend the rest of this review going balls deep:  It sucks that there are so few weapons.  You get new attachements, and they can really alter the way the weapon works, but there are only actually a handful of death implements.  This bothers me  because  A.) The sheer amount of guns there are in Fc3, and B.) Because of how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing cool potential weapons could have been.  The guns that are in the game are simply common archetypes - there's a shotty, sniper, AR, etc.  That's not necessarily an issue, but given how creative the rest of the game is, I can't help but hold it to a high standard.

Now on to the good stuff.

I'm going to tell you the very moment I fell in love with this game.  I had just loaded it up, watched a truly sick cutscene and sprayed down a bunch of future cyberninjas with a helicopter mounted minigun.  The helicopter lands, and I receive a comm message informing me that the tutorial is starting. Without missing a beat, my character screams  I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING HATE TUTORIALS ".


Hilarious though it was
date: this moment is also very significant.  It's Blood Dragon's way of letting you know exactly what it is
hoursPlayed: right as the game starts.  It is a fun spinoff of a popular game franchise.  It is not DLC.  It is not an expansion pack.  It is a stand alone experience that doesn't take itself to seriously.  It is a love letter to the movies
voteText: stories and games that many of us grew up on. It is charming
votesHelpful:
and it is incredibly engaging.


You take control of a cybernetic super soldier tasked with unraveling the defection of your former superiour officer.  The story itself is pretty cookie cutter
votesTotal: but the way it is told is anything but.  Cutscenes are an anachronistic fusion between the 8-bit era and modern flair.  Though the story failed to captivate me
votesFunny:
the dialogue was frequently a highlight.  Blood Dragon thrives on it's unique brand of tongue-in-cheek humor.


Storywise - zero carry over from anything Far Cry
commentsCount: but there are quite a few similarities in the gameplay.  There are animals to hunt
column16: there are unlockables to find and missions often play out exactly like clearing a compound in Far Cry 3.  The bones of it are the same
column17: but not quite as deep (understandable
column18: given the games bargain price point).  Aiming is almost exactly the same as FC3 - there is still that kind of "floaty" element to it which usually necessitates aiming down the sights to hit a shot.   There are not as many weapons to unlock
column19: but the level of upgrades available for your arsenal per weapon is much improved.  Your relationship with your weaponry is a lot more intimate
column20:
and doing missions to earn these upgrades will be where you'll spend a lot of your time.


As a gamer
column21: the thing that I find most appealing is atmosphere.  This isn't something that can be quantified
column22: nor is it the result of any one thing.  It is the pervasive feeling you have while playing the game.  Blood Dragon has a very unique and powerful atmosphere.  The neon juxtaposed by the darkness of the island itself is amazing.  Running in terror from the eponymous Blood Dragon's (or alternatively using them as attack dogs) is a thrill.  Using your cyber ninja stars/samurai sword for stealth kill combos just feels right.  Watching a cyber ninja's head explode in electric sparks after a perfect headshot is satisfaction squared.  All of these things contribute to atmosphere
column23:
but they are only parts of the whole.


The thing that I love most about Blood Dragon is that it exists.  That a triple-a game studio like Ubisoft let their employees run wild and create something that was fun to them is incredible to me.  It isn't a (true) sequel
column24: it isn't made to nickel and dime you
column25: it was a bunch of people creating something cool for the joy of it.  This more than anything speaks to the feel of the game.  The soul of fun and creativity is apparent in literally every part and every moment of FarCry3: Blood Dragon.  I cannot recommend it enough
column26: and I hope that we see more of its kind.\n\n8.5/10"

reviewText: The year is 2007. It is the future."\n\nThis is an absolute blast of an FPS

you won't be disappointed.

Pros:

reviewText: Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is an expertly crafted work of art in its highest form. Not only featuring smooth gameplay and stunning visuals, the game's story, atmosphere, and writing combine to create a post-modernist satire of the past era for those of today. One doesn't have to be born in the 80's to see how every detail- from the animations of the Omega Force to the way Rex Power-Colt swims- combine to form a hilarious satire of the nuclear-future-obsessed films of the Reagan age. The game is also enjoyed in other languages, where the acting is always superb. (A character in the game retains his Japanese accent in all five dubbed languages.) This is a game on my must play list. To quote a character, ‚ÄúAfter all, anyone who thinks that video games cause violence are f---ing idiots.‚Äù

reviewText:

reviewText:
A very fun firstperson-shooter with beautiful graphics in an 80's retro-style inspired world.
This is one of the funniest games I've had the joy of playing - the writing is incredibly entertaining and hilarious. It mocks pretty much everything that revolves around cheesy movie elements (lines, story, characters etc.) and other 80's related business.
The game doesn't overstay its welcome with about 4 hours of an enjoyable story. Of course, should you choose to do so, you do have the option of doing various side-missions (hunting, outposts..) and collecting collectables.

Also, NO RADIO TOWERS. Hooray!

The game is open world, however the map is smaller than that of Far Cry 3, and you are much less encouraged to actually explore it since it's packed with a short story that expects you to follow it during your time playing the game and doesn't tell you or show you much regarding other open world related activities.
Of course exploring it can be (and is) fun nonetheless.

Cons: Uplay / supporting Ubisoft.

Other than that, it's an experience worth having. Especially considering you can have the game for less than $4 during sales.

reviewText: For starters, 3rd party launchers like UPlay that need to always be online can suck my d!ck.\nNow, as for the game,\nIt's worth the 80's nostalge trip, with the self-aware videogame/movie tropes. And it rides that horse all the way into the sunset. There are four or five main missions that are each ~20 to 30 minutes of game time. The rest is two types of side quests; Rescue a scientist or hunt an animal type, Liberating outposts, And collecting TV's, Tapes, and Files, which DOES unlock weapon stuff so it's worthwhile. The island is fairly small, and you can fast travel. I liked it enough to see it through to 100% completion in less than 8 hours. But after all the novelty had worn off, this game left me wanting to go back and play Far Cry 3 again instead of ever planning on playing this again. As of this writing, the pricetag is $15, but I would definitely wait until it's on sale.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game more. Certainly for anyone who remembers it's source material, but for any early '90's kid' who grew up on their older brother's 80's cartoons, their parents 80's action VHS tapes, and was entranced by the cartoons of their own era that still had that offbeat style that haunts them to this day. For those of you who see modern cartoons that lack the macho hero, the two-dimensional love interest, and the evil cyborg who wants to control the world. The shows that take themselves too seriously and are slathered with so many unsubtle moral messages they make no sense. For those of you who have had their experience ruined by modern storytelling and adult cynicism.
This game is your outlet.
Everything you miss about those old cartoons and action heroes.
Crammed with references to series I never thought I'd hear about again (And some I never have, I'm sure), characters ripped straight out of more of the same, and a soundtrack so full of 80's synth you'll have flashbacks.
And of course, more one-liners than I've heard from Arnie, Stalone, and Van Damme.
Combined.
Blood Dragon's action and story moments are what you're here for. A barebones kill-the-bad-guy plot that's not about who you're after, but how you take him down, and how everything explodes nonsensically along the way.
The gameplay is simple enough to understand, effectively identical to Far Cry. For those not familiar with it, don't panic. It's a brilliant system reknowned for attention to realistic detail that plays well into the action-movie aesthetic Blood Dragon draws from. Even some of the weapons here are movie references.
Perhaps the strangest part of Blood Dragon is the moments between its story and combat that provide moments for reflection, particularly with the travel methods taken from the Far Cry series.
It is in these moments that you are likely to notice Blood Dragon's flaws, of which there are very, very few.
Perhaps the most voiced flaw of Blood Dragon is the requirement of a UPlay acount to play Blood Dragon, as it is a Ubisoft game. This can be a valid concern, as loss of any account details can mean a lack of access to the game and requirement of technical support. Every buyer should take care in setting up their UPlay account if they do not have one already. The experience of Blood Dragon is too good to ruin with haphazard account setup, and is most definitely worth it.

The first of the game's ACTUAL arguable flaws is its length. Blood Dragon is definitely not a very long game, and after your first full playthrough, you're likely to notice that there is nothing else out there except a week long 80's movie marathon that can come close to the feeling of your first Blood Dragon playthrough. Which is it's second flaw, the difficulty in defining why Blood Dragon captures its nostalgic essence so well can make it difficult to find anything like Blood Dragon except... More Blood Dragon. Or trying to watch Jonny Quest and Terminator at the same time while posing Dino Riders figures.
Besides the possibility of account issues, Blood Dragon's only downfall as a standalone game may be that there isn't more of it. Or that it's not a war simulator that's been rehashed twelve times for its multiplayer.

Blood Dragon delivers where a lot of games fail, making your protagonist a certified hero you WANT to play as. Rex 'Powers' Colt has no flaws, except maybe that he's TOO badass.
And he's voiced by Michael Bien, who might not be the BEST known action star, but he's the hero from Terminator. And he's in Aliens, so Rex Colt really IS an 80's action hero.

Anyone who feels a pang of nostalgia the moment someone mentions aliens of any kind, has a fear of man-eating sharks with uninspired names, or says 'I'll be back.' without even the slightest hint of an Austrian accent will find a moment of solace in Blood Dragon.

reviewText:
First off, Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon requires a 3rd party program, the universally loathed uPlay. You need to go through all the hassle of creating exceptions for your firewall for uPlay and register an account. It needs to be active all the time you're playing, and if you are a smart enough user to not play on your administrator account (as you should), you'll be bugged to enter your administrator password each and every time you start the game.

About the game itself, Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is a console game and it shows. You cannot bind anything to the mousewheel, all the audio is incredibly quiet even with the volume on max and no way to increase it. The menus and interface are a complete mess with unintuitive controls, open and close slowly and the only thing they succeed at is making you want to use them as little as possible. You have only a single save slot per game, you cannot replay any particular level if you ever want to, and you can't even save when on a mission. Every time a wild animal catches you, you get a quicktime event, which usually leads to your death because the keys it requires you to spam are different every time.

The content of the game itself is pretty well designed. It's a parody game using pretty much every known clich√© of the 80s/90s action movies in an 80s future vision setting.
Most of the weapons are fun to use, though some require you to unlock and buy upgrades to not be useless, such as explosive ammo for the sniper rifle.
You are dropped on an island where you can roam around as you please, follow the main story, side quests or do whatever. While I generally like games with an open world, I feel there is some lack of direction. STALKER games have shown how to do an open world properly while still maintaining a good sense of direction.

A big plus of Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is the music. It's one of the best soundtracks heard in computer gaming and fits the general theme of the game perfectly. Now if only it wasn't so damn quiet you could barely hear anything...

All in all, this is a good FPS plagued by some issues around it. I feel that the positives of the game, mainly the setting, music and over-the-top action hero theme, outweight the negatives and make it worth playing.

reviewText: If you've played Far Cry 3, get this game. If you haven't, get it anyways. This is the game comes straight from the 70s, 80s, and 90s all rolled into one, to give us a neon-filled, nostalgia-fuelled cyber-shooter. You play as a cyber commando, fighting other cyber commandos, and there are DRAGONS WITH FRICKIN' LASERS IN THEIR EYES. Lots of fun references, including Robocop and Predator, hilarious dialogue and jokes, and probably some of the funniest writing outisde of the Borderlands series. However, combat can often get repetitive with the many garrisons that you have to raid. Also, you can't fly a helicopter, but you drive something much better that I cannot say without ruining some ascpect of the game. Probably the one and only real problem that I've had with this game was that it was launched through UPlay. It just gets in the way. Plus, the main campaign is fairly short, but hey, pick it up during a sale, and it's definitely worth it.\n8.5/10 Would 100% complete this game.

reviewText: The loss of talent trees to a linear progression was a nice change, because the xp progression seems to be accelerated compared to FarCry 3. But the music  and the colour saturation. Oh... C'√©tait magnifique! Vous devez le voir! The game is beautiful, you have to see the game... That was initially; later, a haze grew over me made me think that the colour palate (that seemed to be based on parody... What am I saying!?) was not completely easy on the eyes. The gameplay is FarCry 3... WITHOUT HORRIBLE MODERN GAME TROPES! (Except for weapon limits, those are there and that pisses me off.) You can jump off a cliff and not suffer from fall damage. That made the hunting in the game so much fun with the varied and obnoxious arsenal (more based on classic PC shooters than modern games). Did I say that the sniper rifle has an explosive add-on?

reviewText: Far Cry 3 gets the non-serious and reference-filled" treatment with this expansion. Even though it takes place on an open world like its base game
hoursPlayed: and cleaned up quite a bit. When you're not engaging in the batshit crazy story
voteText: you're capturing garrisons and collecting collectibles. Being able to sprint infinitely and quickly combined with no fall damage makes for a game that's less about the world around you and more about you: a cyborg out for blue neon blood.\n\nAs mentioned
votesHelpful: most of it hides behind cutscenes that
votesTotal: while nicely-drawn and humrous
commentsCount: seven-second pauses in between each line. You won't miss any plot if you skip these
column16: but you might miss little nuggets of good writing.\n\nAlso of issue are the titular Blood Dragons. While cool-looking and initially fearsome
column17: you'll get enough firepower during your travels to turn them into more of a nuisance than a terror-inspiring boss. The other enemies you'll come accross
column18: cyber-soldiers and cyber-animals
column19: don't put up much of a fight unless they're in big numbers. Despite this
column21: and the game stays true to the goal of making you feel like a badass.\n\nIf you don't like Uplay
column22: then I've got bad news for you: you need to install Uplay and create an Ubisoft account to play this game (assuming you haven't done either of those already). Uplay isn't really a pain to get set-up
column24: but it does add another weird layer to playing this game and it's one more program I have to install on my computer when I'd prefer to keep it as lean and clean as possible.\n\nAll in all
column25: Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is a fun halfway between linear and open-world
column26: with lots of ways to approach enemies and a fairly formidable enemy in the Blood Dragons. It's the perfect length for an expansion and the setting is well-crafted
column27: albeit hampered by an absurdly slow narrative."

reviewText:

Pros:

- ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• loads of neon, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• loads of explosions

Cons:

- sadly this is only an expansion, so it's pretty short
- Uplay

reviewText:
A very fun firstperson-shooter with beautiful graphics in an 80's retro-style inspired world.
This is one of the funniest games I've had the joy of playing - the writing is incredibly entertaining and hilarious. It mocks pretty much everything that revolves around cheesy movie elements (lines, story, characters etc.) and other 80's related business.
The game doesn't overstay its welcome with about 4 hours of an enjoyable story. Of course, should you choose to do so, you do have the option of doing various side-missions (hunting, outposts..) and collecting collectables.

Also, NO RADIO TOWERS. Hooray!

The game is open world, however the map is smaller than that of Far Cry 3, and you are much less encouraged to actually explore it since it's packed with a short story that expects you to follow it during your time playing the game and doesn't tell you or show you much regarding other open world related activities.
Of course exploring it can be (and is) fun nonetheless.

Cons: Uplay / supporting Ubisoft.

Other than that, it's an experience worth having. Especially considering you can have the game for less than $4 during sales.
